Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support student participation to the Midwest Programming Languages Summit 2016, to be held at the University of Chicago in late Fall 2016. The meeting is an informal regional workshop with the goal of cultivating a regional research network in programming languages and allied topics. The funds will help support students at US universities, focusing on students presenting at the meeting, students from underrepresented minorities, and students who would otherwise not be able to attend due to financial limitations. Supporting student travel to attend professional conferences and workshops is a very important mission of the NSF. Broader impacts include training the next generation of researchers in this important research area and to facilitate their career development in graduate school and subsequently in research, industry, and other sectors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Midwest PL Summit brings together researchers and students from the greater Midwest region to present research advances in programming language technology. Topics include type systems and program logics for software verification; high-performance compiler implementations for parallel and multi-core hardware; tools and techniques for software engineering; Web application security; and the application of programming language technology to diverse settings such as quantum computing and human-computer interaction.

In contrast to more formal conference and workshop venues organized by ACM and IEEE, the Midwest PL Summit serves as a valuable forum for researchers and students to share in-progress research ideas and receive timely feedback to influence subsequent work. This is particularly valuable to provide graduate students opportunities to network and further develop their research and presentation skills.

The second edition of the Midwest PL Summit was a one-day event held on Friday, December 2 on the University of Chicago campus in Chicago, IL. Approximately 100 participants attended, including approximately 20 faculty, 60 Ph.D. and Masters students, 15 undergraduates, and 5 software engineers and practitioners in industry. Attendees represented 12 different colleges and universities and 6 companies from 7 states (Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Minnesota, Wisconsin, and even California).

The program for the Summit consisted of 14 research presentations (delivered by a variety of faculty, graduate, and undergraduate student presenters), 16 research posters presented by graduate and undergraduate students, and several unstructured break and meal times to facilitate conversation and networking.

This award funded breakfast, lunch, and an afternoon break so that participants did not need to pay a registration fee to attend the event. The award also funded 10 student participants with travel grants to help defray their costs to attend the event, some of whom would not have been able to attend otherwise. Awards were given based on a combination of factors, including the distance that students would travel, underrepresented groups in science and technology, and the opportunity for undergraduate students to learn about graduate school and academic research.

During an open discussion at the conclusion of the event, participants shared feedback and suggestions that will help to plan productive Midwest PL Summit events in subsequent years.
